questions.body: What are the serious and common side effects of doxycycline?
questions.ideal_answer: Serious effects include severe gastrointestinal symptoms, cardiac rhythm disturbance, dyspnea, renal/hematologic dysfunction, severe headache with visual symptoms, hepatotoxicity (e.g., dark urine, jaundice), and systemic hypersensitivity. Common effects include nausea/vomiting, dyspepsia, mild diarrhea, pruritic rash, transient skin darkening, and vaginal irritation/discharge.

snippets.text: Serious adverse effects (doxycycline): severe stomach pain; watery/bloody diarrhea; throat irritation or dysphagia; chest pain; irregular heart rhythm; shortness of breath; oliguria/anuria; signs of low WBC (fever, chills, swollen glands, body aches, weakness, pallor, easy bruising/bleeding); severe headache; tinnitus; dizziness; visual disturbances; pain behind eyes; loss of appetite; upper abdominal pain radiating to back; fatigue; vomiting; tachycardia; dark urine; jaundice.
Common adverse effects (doxycycline): nausea, vomiting, upset stomach, loss of appetite, mild diarrhea, skin rash or pruritus, transient darkening of skin, and vaginal itching or discharge.

questions.body: Among drugs used for Acne, which are best rated by patients?
questions.ideal_answer: Top patient-rated therapies include isotretinoin and adapalene/benzoyl peroxide combinations, with doxycycline and branded fixed-dose topical retinoid/antibiotic products also highly rated by review count and mean score.

snippets.text: Isotretinoin: high mean rating with substantial review count for Acne.
Adapalene/benzoyl peroxide combination (e.g., Epiduo): strong patient ratings and reviews.
Doxycycline (Acne use): mid-to-high rating with numerous reviews indicating effectiveness.
Fixed-dose topical retinoid/antibiotic products: competitive mean ratings within Acne cohort.
Additional high-rated Acne therapies corroborating isotretinoin and BPO/retinoid positioning.

questions.body: Is doxycycline Rx or OTC, what is its pregnancy category, and what are its brand names?
questions.ideal_answer: Doxycycline is prescription-only (Rx). Use in pregnancy is contraindicated/avoided. Representative brands include Acticlate, Adoxa (various), Avidoxy, Doryx, Monodox/Mondoxyne NL, Morgidox, Oracea, Oraxyl, Periostat, Vibramycin (calcium/hyclate/monohydrate), and Vibra-Tabs.

snippets.text: Facts (doxycycline): Rx only; pregnancy category avoid/contraindicated; brands include Acticlate, Adoxa family, Avidoxy, Doryx, Monodox/Mondoxyne NL, Morgidox, Oracea, Oraxyl, Periostat, Vibramycin (calcium/hyclate/monohydrate), Vibra-Tabs.

questions.body: What are alternative drugs related to doxycycline (with links)?
questions.ideal_answer: Related alternatives include amoxicillin, azithromycin, ciprofloxacin, cephalexin, metronidazole (oral/topical), clindamycin (oral/topical), prednisone, and albuterol, with source links provided in the dataset.

snippets.text: Related set (doxycycline) with links: amoxicillin; azithromycin; ciprofloxacin; cephalexin; metronidazole (oral/topical); clindamycin (oral/topical); prednisone; albuterol.

questions.body: For Acne, which options look pregnancy-safe?
questions.ideal_answer: Entries marked as pregnancy-safer include topical clindamycin and select β-lactams such as cephalexin; these show more favorable pregnancy categories than tetracyclines.

snippets.text: Pregnancy category favorable (Acne): topical clindamycin noted as safer option.

questions.body: Which OTC options exist for Acne?
questions.ideal_answer: Over-the-counter options emphasize benzoyl peroxide (various strengths and formulations) and sulfur/resorcinol combinations, exemplified by PanOxyl and similar BPO products.

snippets.text: OTC Acne: benzoyl peroxide gels/cleansers (multiple strengths).
OTC Acne: benzoyl peroxide washes (e.g., PanOxyl line variants).
OTC Acne: sulfur/resorcinol combinations listed as alternatives.
OTC Acne examples: additional BPO-branded products for over-the-counter use.
OTC Acne: confirmation of multiple nonprescription BPO formulations.

questions.body: List drugs that belong to the class: upper respiratory combinations
questions.ideal_answer: Examples include multi-ingredient cold/flu products such as Theraflu Nighttime Severe Cold & Cough, acetaminophen/chlorpheniramine/phenylephrine combinations, pseudoephedrine/triprolidine combinations, Tylenol Cold, and Mucinex Fast-Max Night Time Cold & Flu.
